selected_quotes: New Pediatrics study/commentary look at 20 year follow-up effects of kangaroo mother care.
Amazing follow up of children in Kangaroo Mother Care RCT, 20 Years

citation.title: Kangaroo Mother Care 20 Years Later: Connecting Infants and Families

news.title: What We Can Learn from Kangaroos
news.summary: Source: Randi Hutter Epstein What a nice scientific study to read on my son’s twenty-third birthday.

news.title: Benefits of 'Kangaroo Mother Care': Do They Last?
news.summary: 10:28am ET MORE Credit: Travel_Master/Shutterstock.com Vulnerable babies who are held close by their parents, skin to skin, may reap the benefits of this so-called "kangaroo mother care" for at least two decades, according to a new study from…

news.title: Benefits of 'Kangaroo Mother Care': Do They Last?
news.summary: More Vulnerable babies who are held close by their parents, skin to skin, may reap the benefits of this so-called "kangaroo mother care" for at least two decades, according to a new study from Colombia.

news.title: Benefits of 'Kangaroo Mother Care': Do They Last?
news.summary: Vulnerable babies who are held close by their parents, skin to skin, may reap the benefits of this so-called “ kangaroo mother care ” for at least two decades, according to a new study from Colombia.

news.title: Benefits of 'Kangaroo Mother Care': Do They Last?
news.summary: More Vulnerable babies who are held close by their parents, skin to skin, may reap the benefits of this so-called "kangaroo mother care" for at least two decades, according to a new study from Colombia.

news.title: Benefits of 'Kangaroo Mother Care': Do They Last?
news.summary: More Vulnerable babies who are held close by their parents, skin to skin, may reap the benefits of this so-called "kangaroo mother care" for at least two decades, according to a new study from Colombia.

news.title: Benefits of "Kangaroo Mother Care" May Last 20 Years or More
news.summary: Vulnerable babies who are held close by their parents, skin to skin, may reap the benefits of this so-called “kangaroo mother care” for at least two decades, according to a new study from Colombia.

news.title: 'Kangaroo Mother Care' May Improve Preemies' Lives Into Adulthood
news.summary: By Karen Pallarito HealthDay Reporter MONDAY, Dec. 12, 2016 (HealthDay News) -- When Einat Zemach's son was born early at 32 weeks' gestation, she and her husband would snuggle him skin-to-skin upon their chests for two or three hours at a time.

news.title: Skin-to-skin ‘kangaroo’ baby care tied to better health years later
news.summary: By (Reuters Health) - Premature and underweight newborns may be healthier as children and young adults if they pass their early days with their bare chests nestled directly against their mothers’ breasts, a new study suggests.

news.title: Cash may get more mothers to breastfeed babies

news.title: Mothers Who Breastfeed Should Receive Cash? Study Reveals Incentive Might Encourage Moms To Maintain Breastfeeding
news.summary: The challenge of breastfeeding might become more appealing to mothers if they are given a cash incentive.

news.title: Mothers Who Breastfeed Should Receive Cash? Study Reveals Incentive Might Encourage Moms To Maintain Breastfeeding

news.title: Paying Low-Income Moms to Breastfeed Might Raise Breastfeeding Rates, But Is It Ethical?
news.summary: Thinkstock/bmcent1 The benefits of breastfeeding are often exaggerated, but everyone can agree that women should have the resources to breastfeed their infants if they so choose.

news.title: Cash may get more mothers to breastfeed
news.summary: CEBU, Philippines - Cash incentives may encourage new mothers to breastfeed until their infants are at least six months old, a small experiment suggests.
